text.p: These are the highlights of the main Sao Paulo and Rio de Janeiro newspapers this morning.
-- GOVERNMENT ACTS TO CALM FOREX AND INTEREST RATES MKTS

The government sold on Monday 650 million of National Treasury Notes (NTNs) indexed to the dollar, paying annual yields of 13.95 percent, in a move to curb speculation over the foreign exchange rate in the financial markets.

A restructuring plan launched by Bamerindus group earlier this year could not prevent the bank from showing a 54.2 million real loss in the third quarter. The quarterly losses erased the bank's first-half 20 million real profit. In nine months, Bamerindus reported losses of 33.8 million reais.
-- MALAN SEES NATURAL STABILIZATION OF THE ECONOMY

Finance Minister Pedro Malan said the government has no plans to adopt measures to slow down the economy. He said Brazil's GDP grew seven percent in the third quarter, but added the economy will close the year with a three percent growth rate.
-- TAX ON NON PRODUCTIVE LAND TO RISE
The federal government on Tuesday will send to Congress a proposal to raise by 300 percent on average a tax on rural areas. Lands which are not considered productive would pay more.
Treasury's deficit so far this year has totalled 6.392 billion reais, an increase of 182 percent against the same period of 1995.
-- U.S. CONSULATE ADMITS GRANTING VISA TO BOY

The U.S. Consulate in Rio de Janeiro denied it has refused to grant a visa for a black Brazilian boy for race reasons. The Consulate, alleging the boy's parents failed to provide required information, now admits reconsidering its decision.
-- Reuters has not verified these stories and cannot vouch for their accuracy.
